MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Congestion in Mayo.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands if he is aware that acute congestion exists in the townland of Ara South, Balla, County Mayo; that there are ten tenants in that townland whose poor law valuations are under £3 each; that there are several untenanted holdings in that townland and vicinity let in grazing; and, if he will state what steps, if any, are being taken by the Land Commission to provide economic holdings for the tenants in this townland.

The Land Commission are aware of the congestion in the townland of Ara and are taking steps to relieve it. They have completed the resumption of one holding of 5 acres, 1 rood, 15 perches, in the adjoining townland of Aghaluskey and are taking proceedings for the resumption of three further holdings comprising a total area of 36 acres, 3 roods, 24 perches in the townland of Ara and Aghaluskey.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Turf Supplies in County Kildare.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands if he is aware that the turf banks attached to the holdings of several persons in the townland of Newtown-Donore are cut away, with the result that the owners are compelled to rent other banks at high rates; if so, whether it is the intention of the Land Commission to acquire for allotment amongst persons requiring turf banks, the large tract of undeveloped bog in the Newtown-Donore and adjoining townlands.

The Land Commission are making inquiries regarding lands in Newtown-Donore district, including turbary, and the needs of the tenants in that townland will be considered in the event of suitable turbary being acquired.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Uneconomic Holdings in County Kildare.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands if he is aware that in the townland of Newtown-Donore there is a number of uneconomic holders of a very industrious type, who cultivate their holdings in a husbandlike manner; and, if so, whether it is the intention of the Land Commission to acquire for allotment amongst those uneconomic holders lands in that townland and in adjoining townlands, which are not being cultivated industriously.
The Land Commission are aware of the congestion in the townland of Newtown-Donore, and they are making enquiries regarding lands in that district with a view to acquisition.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Value of Butter Industry.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will state the total quantity and value of (a) creamery butter and (b) factory butter, manufactured during each of the years 1931, 1932, 1933, 1934, 1935, 1936, 1937 and 1938, inclusive, and the total quantity and value of (a) creamery butter and (b) factory butter exported during each of these years; and if he will state what amount, if any, of the value of the goods so exported represents subsidies, bounties or other such payments.

The statistics of creamery and factory butter manufactured in the years 1931 and 1936 will be found on page 41 of the “Census of Industrial Production,” 1936 (P. No. 3143) and for the year 1937 on page 231 of the “Irish Trade Journal and Statistical Bulletin,” December, 1938. Particulars of the value of creamery butter and the quantity and value of factory butter manufactured are not available for the years 1932 to 1935 inclusive, but the quantities of creamery butter manufactured in these years are shown on page 56 of the “Statistical Abstract,” 1937 (P. No. 2750). Statistics of the value of creamery butter and the quantity and value of factory butter manufactured in the year 1938 are not yet available. The quantity of creamery butter manufactured in 1938 was 766,460 cwt.

MainHeading.P: Statistics of creamery butter and factory butter exported in each of the years 1931-1938, are published in the annual “Trade and Shipping Statistics” and the monthly “Trade Statistics”; those for the years 1931 to 1933 on page 152 of the annual “Trade and Shipping Statistics,” 1934 (P. No. 1807); those for the years 1934 to 1937 on page 185 of annual “Trade and Shipping Statistics,” 1937 (P. No. 3121), and those for the year 1938 on page 16 of the “Trade Statistics,” December, 1938.

Exporters are definitely instructed that the values in their declarations furnished to customs must represent only the cost, insurance and freight to the sea or land frontier of this country and must not include the value of any bounty or subsidy. Every effort was made by examination and inquiry to eliminate the effect of such inclusion, which may have been made especially in the earlier of the years referred to, and it is considered that the extent of error in the statistics on the account is negligibly small.
